title: Ticket #1578: Removing jobs via SOAP interface does not set terminal status on job
description:
The history file contains jobs with their JobStatus set to non-terminal values if you use the SOAP interface to remove a job the status of the job in the history file remains as it was when the job was removed. It's not set to C or X, which is what happens if you remove a job condor_rm.

Example: 

  >condor_history 48.10
  ID      OWNER            SUBMITTED     RUN_TIME ST   COMPLETED CMD
  48.10  Administrator   8/12 22:44   0+00:00:00 I   ???        \\htpc\nas\jobs

And for a held job: 

  >condor_q 48.16
  -- Submitter: winxpcm : <192.168.0.173:4501> : winxpcm
  ID      OWNER            SUBMITTED     RUN_TIME ST PRI SIZE CMD
  48.16  Administrator   8/12 22:44   0+00:00:00 H  0   0.0  run.bat


  -- sanity check to make sure there's nothing about job in the history file --


  >condor_q 48.16
  -- Submitter: winxpcm : <192.168.0.173:4501> : winxpcm
   ID      OWNER            SUBMITTED     RUN_TIME ST PRI SIZE CMD


   -- job was removed via the SOAP interface --


  >condor_history 48.16
  ID      OWNER            SUBMITTED     RUN_TIME ST   COMPLETED CMD
  48.16  Administrator   8/12 22:44   0+00:00:00     ???        \\htpc\nas\jobs

Technically all jobs in the history file should be jobs that are in terminal states.

Easy to reproduce: put jobs in queue, issue SOAP calls to remove them when they are in states other than queued. Only tested, reproduced on WinXP so far.

Looks like the SOAP remove is just missing: 

  jobStatus = REMOVED;
  jobAd->Assign(ATTR_JOB_STATUS, jobStatus);

Before AppendHistory() is called.

I'm attaching a history file that shows jobs in states not terminal in it.
remarks:
2010-Aug-13 06:13:09 by matt:
Do you see this same problem with jobs removed via PeriodicRemove?

There are two code path in the code for removing clusters and procs, bad, and they should be unified.

Please include the code you are using to call removeJob, or at least the arguments.

The Broken Version is meant to reflect the first version this became a problem, going back to as far as 7.0.0. Was this an issue in 7.4.1 or earlier?

2010-Aug-13 08:56:25 by ichesal:
Matt, I haven't tried PeriodicRemove, but I can. I'll report back.

The code I'm using to do the remove is: 

  import condor.birdbath.Schedd;
  import condor.birdbath.Transaction;


  public void removeJobs(Transaction transaction, FullJobId[] jobIds, String reason, SchedulerDaemon schedulerDaemon)
  throws RemoteException
  {
      Schedd condorSchedd = new Schedd(new URL("http://" + schedulerDaemon.getDaemonAddress()));
      Transaction transaction = condorSchedd.createTransaction();
      transaction.begin(120);


      for (int index = 0; index < jobIds.length; ++index)
      {
          FullJobId id = jobIds[index];
          transaction.removeJob(id.cluster, id.job, reason);
      }


      transaction.commit();
  }

First saw the problem in 7.0.4 but was able to reproduce it in 7.4.2 before filing this ticket.

2010-Aug-13 10:01:11 by ichesal:
Correction: no, I don't see this problem with a periodic_remove statement that removes idle and running jobs.

2012-Jun-19 15:54:15 by ichesal:
This persists in 7.6.6 -- takes nothing special to cause it to happen. Just try to remove job with the SOAP API.
